newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - SFE wheat turns active on profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - SFE wheat turns active on profit-taking.

text.p: Wheat futures fell moderately in active trading on profit-taking on the Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) on Tuesday.
Brokers, buoyed by the more active market, said there was good buying support at lower levels across the board.
Market leader January 1997, which opened at A$149.50 and closed at A$152.50 on settlement prices, found very strong support at A$150.00, said Phil Lindsay of Ord Minnett Jardine Fleming Futures Ltd.
January 1997, March 1997, May and July all traded between 50 cents and A$3.00 lower, with 55 contracts changing hands.
Lindsay said a more active market was a healthy sign and profit-taking had the potential to produce a technical rally.
Chartists were predicting Chicago would bottom tonight.
"We may be near the lows for ASW (Australian Standard White) based on that," he said.
Rumours that Russia was looking for two million tonnes of feed wheat, from either Canada or Australia, was also supportive for the ASW contract, he said.
But the increased estimate by ABARE for a 1996/97 Australian crop of 20.9 million tonnes was a negative, as ABARE approached Ord Minnett's estimate of slightly above 22 million tonnes.
End users also remained out of the futures market, with flour mills and feed mills buying hand-to-mouth, he said.
The Australian Wheat Board's A$5.00 pool price cut had no impact on futures, which led the pool price cut, he said.
